answer_strings: Hence those economists err who believe, or affect to believe, that political economy is nothing else than an application of mathematics, and that in time it will be reduced to this.
Hence those economists are correct who believe, or affect to believe, that political economy is something more than an application of mathematics, and that in time it will not be reduced to this.
Hence, though the economist does not occupy himself with the attributes of God or with the supreme principles of morality, his teaching cannot on this account be called irreligious or immoral.

Thus by giving it its due place we take away the pretext of those enemies of political economy who, as we shall see, reproach it with giving its whole attention to products, regardless of the lot of those who create and consume them.
It follows that the consumption patterns, thence the economic decisions related to food purchases, are influenced significantly by subjective opinions regarding supply.

Notwithstanding, within certain limits and in treating of exactly appreciable quantities, we may apply mathematics to the economic science.

Thus, as has before been noticed, an economic art might not exist on the hypothesis of a human society with no political constitution and no need of government, in which case there could of course be no such thing as economic politics.

Hence it may be inferred that political economy has a twofold importance; theoretical with regard to the pure science and to the usefulness of the knowledge it gives; practical with regard to the applied science, and the advantage which may be drawn in public and private life from the guiding principles which it points out.

Hence economic politics is in its turn subdivided into two parts, namely: (a) economic politics in the strict sense, which directs the action of public powers with regard to private wealth, and (b) the science of finance, which sets forth guiding principles for the better administration of the public wealth.
Thus, it follows that both spheres are governed and influenced by these principles, making their study indispensable to understanding the broader economic landscape.

Consequently, the same analytical tools that illuminate market mechanisms must also be applied to the formulation of public policy, for otherwise the separation of theory and practice would remain an academic abstraction, and the public spheres would be in disarray without integration.
passage: We have said that the distinction between political economy in its proper sense and economic politics, is not equivalent to that between pure and applied political economy. The guiding principles furnished by the economic art refer to private no less than to public affairs. Thus, as has before been noticed, an economic art might exist on the hypothesis of a human society with no political constitution and no need of govern ment, in which case there could of course be no such thing as economic politics.

ground_truth: Thus, as has before been noticed, an economic art might exist on the hypothesis of a human society with no political constitution and no need of govern ment, in which case there could of course be no such thing as economic politics.
